text:
Ok i was just using TinkerCad and noticed there was ALOT of limitations but that is expected on a WEB BASED 3D MODELING... I mean come on.. So i looked in to FUSION360.. and since im a bit older.. i can tell you how i felt reading the changes even years after it happened.

Yall remember Photoshop? Like every single person on the planet knew of and used photoshop at least a few times in their lives.
Then they did the cloud thing.. and guess what.. NO ONE uses photoshop anymore except their super rich nich businesses that already havent moved on to other technology.

Thats the vibe I get. Autodesk was something of a community of free users improving their help and tutorials and user interface. Everyone knew what autodesk was even if you never used its software. 
They will go 100% cloud and be premium for a insane priceing stradegy only to attract the richest of the rich customers all while making their name on the free version no longer offered.

FU Autodesk

Moving on to something else before i get used to your software then you take it away and charge $2600 a year.
video: Fusion 360 - Did Autodesk just kill the FREE Version?

text: I just got mine yesterday and came from glowforge so was super nervous about how user friendly it would be. Everything worked great out of the box- I followed Cam’s setup instructions. I had a couple initial hiccups running it with my Mac (no usb and I needed a usb to usb c conversion and then still my Mac not recognizing it for whatever reasons and next trying to run it through a gfci outlet was a no go and still trying to figure out Wi-Fi/Ethernet connection stuff). But now running lightburn on my daughter’s pc it is working great. Much more powerful /fast/capable than my glowforge plus and wow for the price. If you follow the unboxing and setup videos that are on YouTube, read the manual thoroughly, then it doesn’t take long to understand it and get running. TBD if I can get my Mac to recognize it. Also 7mm hold down pins was my first cut and that appears to be the sweet spot

text:
Glowforge is a compete pos. Prior to buying my 50w Omtech, I rented a Glowforge from a friend, and it was 100% unusable because you HAVE TO scan the bed with the camera prior to every burn. So, if you think you’re going to design something and pound a bunch of them out, 1 after the other, you’re going to be seriously disappointed. It makes no difference that every piece is on exactly the same material and there is no need to scan every time. You HAVE TO. Their software is crap and replacement parts are more trouble than their worth.

I had a Lightburn camera on my Omtech. I took it out and threw it away. I can’t imagine what could possibly be the use for something so wildly inaccurate, and that’s after having spent far too much time mastering the calibration procedure. I’d disagree with the statement that Omtech support is great. It’s not. I had an issue with a loose X axis belt. I spent several days going back and forth with them and their suggestions for what to do had nothing - literally zero - to do with the problem, which was a loose belt. I figured it out on my own. Aside from that, I’ve been VERY happy with the machine and I’m coming up on a year of using it for production manufacturing.
video: $4000 cheaper than Glowforge AND better?  OMTech Polar Review

text: If you do wooden coasters, Finish them in a polyurethane or epoxy. I have had amazing luck with Zar solvent based polyurethanes. I have a couple test coasters I made, that I have been abusing for the last year. They have held up flawlessly, no surface degredation, I am constantly putting hot and cold items on it, leaving water on it ... etc. Been amazed at how well it has held up.

Especially if they can give you their store logo art work to put on the top. It's kind of branding the bar so to speak. text:
I find literally the same designs and drawings all over. Researching petroglyphs in Southwest USA turned up two designs created by uncredited authors being sold on mugs, tshirts, woodcraft, metal craft, etc. by at least 10 different sellers... as their own work. This crap is rampant. I can find tshirts with readily available art work being sold at discount stores all over the metro. One guy on youtube publishes a design build, and viewers complain when he doesn't make dimensions or code available.  When a creator does publish build files, code, etc., you can subsequently find that design being sold online as some douche's original work.

Some people are actual creators. Everyone else seems to be ripoff artists.

text: I paid $150,000 for a Laguna DLS 3000w fiber laser. You'd be surprised at what a disappointment it is with both support, software, and performance. Actual real good lasers are a half million or more. Bystronic makes amazing 5000w fiber lasers. I've never had a problem with them
